III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Both female houses are located on the east side of the center of campus. Putnam and
Gerber share housing designs wherein each house is a one-story, ranch-style home
with a basement. The basement is used for group activities, for storage, for doing
laundry, and as a “mud room” for shoes, coats, etc. Each house has a kitchen and a
dining area where the youths eat breakfast, weekend meals, and other meals during
times when the main campus dining area is closed. Each house has a day area/living
room and a bathroom. The sleeping area is in line-of-site of the day area, and consists
of seven bedrooms. Two females sleep in each room, and the additional bedroom is
used for storing clothing. Each bedroom contains shelves for clothing, a bunk bed and
a desk. In addition there is a House Supervisor’s office and a storage room for
toiletries, first aid and medications.
B. Program Description
The female residential program consists of two separate houses – Putnam House,
which serves an abuse/neglect population, and Gerber House, which serves a
delinquency population. The residential program serves female youths ages 12-17 and
their families. These youths are struggling with emotional and behavioral issues to the
2

extent that the youth, the family and/or the community have been negatively impacted,
resulting in the youth being removed from the home and the community.
The program accepts youths from the following.
• DHS Delinquents.
• DHS County offices (abuse/neglect).
• County Court referrals.
• Adoption Subsidy referrals.
• Private referrals.
• School Referrals.
Residential programming is designed to meet the psychological, emotional, behavioral
and spiritual needs of the youth and family. This is done through the following services:
• Individual/group/family counseling.
• Experiential programming including a 12-day wilderness program, weekend
wilderness programs, community service programs and ropes and towers
initiatives.
• Substance abuse counseling groups (when necessary).
• Psychiatric evaluation (when necessary).
• Psychological testing (when necessary).
• Life skills.
• Educational programming.
• Home visits.
• Voluntary chapel programming including chapel services, youth groups, and
spiritual counseling.
• Family weekends.
Youths in Putnam, the abuse/neglect house, tend to stay in care longer than the youths
in Gerber, the delinquency house. A large percentage of the females in both houses
are coping with sexual trauma occurring throughout their lifetime, and with other cultural
issues that may induce unhealthy behavior. For that reason, programming focuses
heavily on health relationships, empowerment, boundaries, and a higher degree of self-
investment and self-sufficiency.
Discharge from the program can occur through Graduation, Escalation, Truancy or
Maximum Benefit. With a discharge due to Graduation, Escalation or Maximum benefit,
the date of termination is established at least 30 days prior to release, so that
transitional counseling and maximizing community support services can occur.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The Eagle Village Gerber-Putnam program was reviewed as part of the overall Eagle
Village, Inc. residential licensing review conducted February 5 and 6 and March 6,
3

2007. All identified rule violations have been corrected, and the facility is in compliance
with all applicable rule areas.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that an Original Provisional License be issued, effective 9/4/2007.
